body: In the late 1970's, while the Bronx was burning, a small cadre of artists gathered in a storefront gallery on Third Street near the Hub at 149th Street, in the heart of a neighborhood rapidly turning to rubble. They put sculptures in abandoned lots, photographed teenagers dancing on linoleum laid over cracked concrete and painted kaleidoscopic
title: Hope Is Artists' Medium In a Bronx Neighborhood; Dancers, Painters and Sculptors Head to Hunts Point

body: IN the 1860's, the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church sheltered runaway slaves in its basement. More than a century later, the church, at South Oxford Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, continues its tradition of social activism. Now its leader, the Rev. David Dyson, needs to raise money to cope with the problems of age in his
title: Streetscapes /Lafayette Avenue Presybyterian Church, Fort Greene, Brooklyn; A Shelter for Runaway Slaves, a Bastion of Activism

body: AMY BENNETT and Morton Dubin, both lawyers, were looking for an apartment to buy on the Upper West Side. One weekend, they went to an open house on 71st Street and were totally depressed by the minuscule bedrooms and pathetic outdoor space. ''It was $750,000 for two closets and a shared garden,'' Mr. Dubin said. On impulse, they jumped on the
title: Habitats /Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn; Couple Find Fort Greene Is Just to Their Taste

body: BRETT COOK-DIZNEY made a name for himself by hanging his spray-painted, graffiti-like murals around the city, where what he calls ''living museums'' comment on everything from Haitian immigration to cloning. Mr. Cook-Dizney takes it as a measure of his success that in many struggling Brooklyn neighborhoods, more people may have seen his hip-hop
title: COPING; A Hip-Hop Artist Brings It All Back Home

body: IT is holiday time. The fateful call has been placed, too late as usual in all likelihood, to purchase tickets to a weekend performance of ''The Nutcracker.'' title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Making The Spirit Go A-Leaping

body: Theater ''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 2 p.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker
title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN

body: Today's buzz is dizzying, barreling prosperity. Skyscrapers are sprouting like Christmas trees, hotels are full, tourists legion. The average price of a Manhattan apartment south of Harlem is $850,000, and buyers must strike like raptors to grab one. Marc M. Goloven, senior regional economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, says that as employment has
title: The Neediest Cases; Prosperity Extends Its Reach, but Not Far Enough to Benefit All

body: Hilda and Samuel Tavarez moved from the Dominican Republic into a home for the city's working poor in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. The building, once a parochial school, was revived by Catholic Charities, one of seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Article, Page 58. THE NEEDIEST CASES
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; A Journey Is Completed

body: NEW YORK QUEENS: TEENAGER FATALLY STRUCK BY VAN -- A 14-year-old Rego Park girl died yesterday after she was struck by a minivan while crossing Queens Boulevard, the police said. The authorities said the girl, Sofia Leviyev, was walking along a crosswalk at 67th Avenue at 5 p.m. Wednesday when she was hit by a Dodge Caravan going west. The car had
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: The set resembles a ghost ship aglow with embers and festooned with sauerkraut. The vocalists sing a lullaby radiating from the ocean's depths. title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; An Eerie Beauty Darkly Smolders

body: Fleet bank has selected Brooklyn as one of four Northeastern communities that will receive an economic development grant, officials said yesterday. The $750,000 award will be used to help attract and stabilize businesses in Fort Greene, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Clinton Hill and will provide merchants and entrepreneurs with technical assistance, said
title: Metro Business Briefing; BANK GRANT FOR BROOKLYN

body: August Strindberg may not have had the snooze alarm in mind when he wrote ''A Dream Play'' in 1901, but maybe Robert Wilson did when he undertook to design and direct it. title: THEATER REVIEW; Strindberg, Influenced by Freudian Sleep

title: Practically Zero Tolerance on Traffic

author: David Rohde, a reporter for The New York Times, received a Pulitzer Prize for his coverage of the fall of Srebrenica for The Christian Science Monitor. He is the author of ''Endgame: The Betrayal and Fall of Srebrenica.''

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL; Red Storm's New Point Guard Is Thinking Final 4

title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; In Stirring Ritual Steps, Past and Present Unfold

title: DANCE REVIEWS; Playful and Painful Contrasts As China Meets Mississippi

body: There were gently churning ceiling fans. There were comfortable cane seats. In the summer, a cool breeze might rustle the pages of your carefully folded newspaper. title: BASEBALL: SUBWAY SERIES -- TUNNEL VISIONS; Subway Cars of the 1950's Evoke Nostalgia, Too

body: It is a curtain call revelation that there are four cast members in ''Maquina Hamlet.'' You might think there are more of them. But until they take their somber bows, the actors have been hard to keep track of, performing as they do without speaking and often wearing rat-head masks among mannequins who are often in similar masks. As a mystery
title: THEATER REVIEW; To Be, Or Not To Be, or Something

body: BY now everyone should be good and tired of thinking about Jimi Hendrix. He may have been the ultimate icon of countercultural rock, but decades have passed since his death. In the hip-hop era, whole new sound worlds have emerged. The three genres Hendrix helped found -- heavy metal, jazz fusion and funk -- have evolved beyond his contributions.
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; A Haze As Ever Purple

body: ''I have spent a lifetime listening to 'I don't understand,' '' Orson Welles complains as the narrator of his own life story, the deconstructed subject of ''War of the Worlds'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL REVIEW; Searching for Welles as Welles Searched for Kane

body: SHE was sitting in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden the other day, feeding a duck out of her hand. She looked serene, as befitted a soon-to-be-ordained Zen priest. ''You can perform legal marriages,'' she said of her impending priesthood, which ''gets the legal clergy status, those parking spaces that say Clergy Only.'' She laughed. Angel Kyodo
title: COPING; A Zen Priest and the Art of Black Serenity

body: BOXING has always provided an apt metaphor for films about struggle and redemption. title: FILM; Now It's Women's Turn to Make It in the Ring

title: THEATER REVIEW; Uneasy Leaders Whose Downfall Lay Within Themselves

body: Joe McCarthy sees Redcoats everywhere in Brooklyn. In his mind's eye, British troops come surging by the tens of thousands off the war boats massed in the Narrows off Bay Ridge, just as they did on the humid, breezy morning of Aug. 27, 1776. They march in endless formation up Fourth Avenue, past the auto body places and worn bodegas, and pelt the
title: Red Cars, Not Coats, And a Cast Of One; Battle of Brooklyn, Evoked on a Budget

title: ART REVIEW; Stretching Definitions Of Outdoor Sculpture

body: To the Editor: Re ''Eagles' Nest in Manhattan Irks Brooklyn'' (news article, May 18), about the issue of the placement of the eagle sculptures originally located in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn: The curatorship of city-owned art is a function of the Art Commission; it is not a function of the parks commissioner. title: Whose Eagle Statues?

body: WHEN brownstones were constructed on block after block of Brooklyn in the late 19th century, they provided housing for well-to-do people whose live-in servants, usually immigrants from Italy, Ireland or Germany, would dust the intricately carved moldings and cook in the ground-floor kitchens, sending food upstairs to the dining room by dumbwaiter.
title: Discovering Bed-Stuy's Brownstones

title: Eagles' Nest In Manhattan Irks Brooklyn; Officials and Veterans Want Statues Returned

body: Let's face it. When it comes to providing high-level, high-suspense soap opera, the British royal family just hasn't been delivering lately. Will the Prince of Wales marry his mistress? Will the Duke and Duchess of York reunite? It's hard to care, frankly. But where is a person with an addiction to palace intrigue, power lust and sexual betrayal to
title: THEATER REVIEW; Vintage Soap Opera (as in Castile Soap)

body: T. S. Eliot scorned his 1939 play ''The Family Reunion'' 11 years after he wrote it. He found Harry, Lord Monchensey, the tortured man at its center, an ''insufferable prig.'' And who can blame him? Here is a prodigal son who comes home to the family estate, Wishwood, after eight years' absence, to celebrate his dying mother's birthday. His gift is
title: THEATER REVIEW; A Dismal Dandy Surrounded by Dull Chatterers

body: JEFFERY AND FAITH LARSEN of Greenwich, Conn., have been anticipating life in an empty nest, now that their children are 14 and 15 years old. So they have decided to move to a new nest. That nest, it turns out, will be an old one, a four-story town house on East 62nd Street built in 1870 and expanded to five stories in 1919. When the Larsens move in
title: Bringing a Town House Back Full Circle

body: Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has always been home to a black middle class, but the Ave belonged to the broke and the bus drivers. The playground belonged to the tough kids like Chulo, who wear flannel and sneakers and whiskers. That was before the Change. The Caucasian invasion, they call it; before the police and the block associations, the bars, cafes
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS; Couple of Homeboys With the Gentrification Blues

body: IT happened so fast it was easy to miss. Brownstones in places like Fort Greene and Harlem are no longer necessarily bargains. A nice house in Harlem might sell for $700,000, double the price of a year ago, according to Yvonne Maddox, manager of Charles H. Greenthal's Harlem office. In Brooklyn's Clinton Hill, house prices have reached $999,995,
title: Habitats/Bedford-Stuyvesant; Finding a Town House With a Sense of History

body: THE Trisha Brown Dance Company usually tours Europe for six weeks each fall before returning to New York, but this year it will spend three months there, then head to Salt Lake City for two weeks. While the troupe is pleased about the lengthened tour, its schedule owes as much to real estate concerns as to artistic considerations. ''The reason
title: When Rent Becomes the Show Stopper; Arts groups, with specialized space demands, are being squeezed by real estate costs

body: NO getting away from it: everywhere in New York City home prices just keep climbing -- from the rarefied heights of Manhattan where 11 apartments have sold for $10 million or more so far this year, compared with just six in all of 1999, to every single ZIP code area in the city's other boroughs. A studio in Manhattan costs 31 percent more than it
title: In All 5 Boroughs, High Goes Higher

body: FOR all the fuss over the glut of new restaurants in Brooklyn, you would think that the Dodgers had come back to town or that, finally, another tree had grown. Or that no promising young chefs were left in Manhattan. Over the past year or so, Smith Street, Park Slope, Fort Greene and Williamsburg have all been proclaimed culinary hot spots of the
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; A Defining Moment In Brooklyn

title: At Poets' Gathering, a Tribute to Diallo

body: It's not a job with a future, but the future of many neighborhoods in America may be affected by how well the job is done. Every 10 years, the Census Bureau hires an army of census takers -- enumerators, in bureau parlance. For the 2000 count, which has just begun, the bureau needs about a half-million of them. The job lasts only six weeks or so.
title: Census Takers Moved by Money And Civic Duty; A Temp Position That Counts, Even if It Doesn't Last Long

body: None of the facts have changed in the year since Amadou Diallo died in his doorway: four white police officers, 41 bullets and one unarmed black man. title: SHADES OF BLUE: A special report.; Diallo Case Yields More Nuanced View of Police

body: The Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York has bought a five-story, 19,200-square-foot building in Fort Greene, about five blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and is leasing it out as office space for use by small theater companies that cannot afford the increasingly high commercial rents in Manhattan. The purchase price was $1.25 million
title: Commercial Real Estate; Brooklyn Offices for Theater Groups

body: A decade after Greyhound stopped direct long-distance service to and from Brooklyn, two local businessmen are trying to return the bus company to the borough. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; Long-Absent Greyhounds May Return To Brooklyn

body: THREE paces down the front walkway, Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez stopped to admire the two-story brick house before him. The home was one of the first his social service organization helped build in Bushwick a decade ago. Since then, he has spurred the construction of hundreds more new houses. ''To me it's beautiful,'' said Mr. Lopez, a towering man
title: The Two Faces of Bushwick; A Troubled Brooklyn Neighborhood Is Mending. But Its Leaders Are Feuding Over the Size of the Gains and What to Do Next.

title: Little Films, Big City: A Love Story; New Yorkers Get Attention, If Not Riches, After Sundance

body: EVENTS Face Time Artists in Roman Egypt from around 30 B.C. to A.D. 305 plied their trade on wooden panels making mummy portraits. Stylistically derived from the Greco-Roman tradition of painting, these works depicted their subject in three-quarter view, with a single light source casting realistic shadows and highlights on the face. But the
title: THIS WEEK

body: GO out in Brooklyn? On the weekend? For groovy New Yorkers, that was once an unbearably tepid proposition. Russian immigrants may drink vodka in Brighton Beach leisure palaces, and Trinidadians let loose to soca near Nostrand Avenue. But the students, artists and hipsters seeking the cultural edge started their evenings on the subway to the Village
title: Brooklyn Nights Turn Brighter

body: Everyone calls her ''Miss,'' but from the time the novel that bears her name was published in 1847, Jane Eyre was a ''Ms.'' waiting to be christened. Capable, intelligent, forthright and even tactless in the face of a perceived injustice, Charlotte Bronte's famous heroine, who undergoes her emotional education within the grueling repressiveness of
title: THEATER REVIEW; An Alter Ego Escapes From the Attic

body: There were four tennis courts and a wall to hit against, all surrounded by acres upon acres of poverty. On this oasis of athleticism, there were kids with big smiles hitting forehands, and a few of them had bare feet. ''The bare truth of tennis is that it takes money,'' said Levar Harper-Griffith, though he stood on these sun-baked hardcourts today
title: Sports of The Times; Tennis Tries to Take Root in Unlikely Soil

body: A state education board yesterday approved the fall opening of 13 new charter schools, including five in New York City and six that will be managed by for-profit companies. The approvals will increase more than fourfold the number of charter schools operating in New York State. The new charter schools, which operate with public funds but are free
title: Boomlet in Charter Schools to Begin in September as New York Approves 13

body: The Artist As a Young Girl Like beauty, art is often in the eye of the beholder. For adult artists -- say, those represented in the Saatchi Collection -- this is a lesson to take in stride. For a fourth-grade painter, however, it's difficult. Take the heroine of ''Noonie's Masterpiece in Purple.'' Noonie says she is a misunderstood genius whose art
title: FAMILY FARE

body: At the Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument, atop a hill in Fort Greene Park, a bronze door has been replaced with plywood, the base is overgrown with grass, two plaques are missing and the light that once blazed on the 148-foot tall Doric column is permanently extinguished. Now an amateur historian in Brooklyn, Robert B. Paterson, is fighting to have the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; As a Monument Crumbles, a Question of Responsibility

body: FLATBUSH Giant Puppets Re-enact Rip's Big Sleep Five giant body puppets towering nine feet, eight costumed characters and a crew of traditional puppets make up the cast of a musical production of ''Rip Van Winkle'' (shown below) at 2 this afternoon at Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts. ''Rip Van Winkle'' is based on the Washington Irving tale
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Police Commissioner Howard Safir has demoted two police precinct commanders who failed to bring down crime in the Brooklyn and Queens neighborhoods patrolled by the officers under their supervision, officials said yesterday. One commander, Capt. James Guida of the 88th Precinct in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, replaced another captain in 1998 who himself
title: Police Demote Commanders Of 2 Precincts

body: On the surface, last year's crime statistics in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, appear alarming: Bucking a trend spanning years, the landmark neighborhood of classical brownstones and leafy streets had recorded a 19.2 percent jump in crimes while reported crime citywide had dropped 8 percent from 1998. But this week, top-ranking police officials said they
title: Precinct's Rosy Crime Rate Was a Distortion, the Police Say

body: WITH little commercial activity and only one subway line to Manhattan, Clinton Hill has long been a place that turns in early for the night. Now, though, this low-profile Brooklyn neighborhood is getting attention from people priced out of other parts of the city. Like its sister neighborhood, Fort Greene, with which it is often compared, Clinton
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; Historic, Diverse and on the Rise
